sub_title: PhD Candidate in Bone-on-a-chip research at Radboud University Medical Center
summary:
I am a PhD Candidate at Radboud University Medical Center. I study the design of visco-elastic biomaterials for use in a bone-on-a-chip, a device that uses human cells to mimic human bone so that we can do medical research on that artificial bone instead of on live animals or humans. 

I did my master’s in chemistry, bio- & nano materials at Uppsala University. I chose this programme specifically because it is so interdisciplinary and because I am interested in applying physical chemistry methods to biochemistry, and in making a difference through biomedical research.
I am particularly interested in working with biomaterials, biosensors, organoids, organs-on-a-chip, microfluidics, drug delivery systems, polymeric materials and other nanobiotechnology such as nanopores for DNA and protein sequencing.

I have always sought to do a bit extra and to satisfy my curiosity. In high school I reached the national finals of the chemistry and biology olympiads, and I participated in a scientific programme for promising students at the local university.
I wanted to study abroad in Scandinavia during the bachelor and rather than letting the language barrier be a problem I worked as an au pair for a year in Stockholm to learn Swedish and start my chemistry studies in Swedish the following year. During the master programme I tried to go on exchange to Kyoto University in Japan but this unfortunately got cancelled twice due to Covid travel restrictions.

In university I got involved in multiple student unions and associations and worked to help assure the quality of the education and the student's interests, as well as organize fun activities. I did many extra courses, the most notable of which is my participation in the student-driven summer research project for the international genetically engineered machine (iGEM) competition. I worked a paid summer project in the same lab that I did my bachelor thesis in and data from that is included in a research paper submitted to ChemCatChem & ChemBioChem pending review. From all these activities I learned organizational skills, confident public speaking and presentations, and collaboration in a large project. 

I have experience with many techniques through the previously mentioned projects as well as my bachelor thesis making and characterizing mutant catalytic enzymes and my master thesis making and characterizing tough ECM-based hydrogels. These include bacterial and yeast cell culture, protein purification, design and synthesis of hydrogels, rheology, differential scanning calorimetry, and tests of material properties.

awards.title: Extraordinary achievement in chemistry exams
awards.description: For getting a 10/10 as my final grade for chemistry
awards.issuer: Nederlandse vereniging voor het onderwijs in de natuurwetenschappen

projects.title: Master thesis - ECM-based hydrogels with ionic interactions
projects.description:
Making tough hydrogels out of ECM-based biomaterials for eventual use in artificial corneas, heart muscle, etc. Specifically the synthesis and evaluation of gelatin hydrogels modified with ionic groups.
Done at the department of macromolecular chemistry at Uppsala University.
Supervisor Ayan Samanta, Subject Specialist Jöns Hilborn.

contributors.headline: PhD Candidate in Bone-on-a-chip research at Radboud University Medical Center

projects.title: Producing enzyme mutants and evaluating their kinetics
projects.description:
3 week paid project producing enzyme mutants and evaluating their kinetics: Catalytic efficiency of FucO mutants N151G and L259V mutants towards low molecular weight aldehydes. The project was done at the lab of professor Mikael Widersten at the department of Biochemistry at Uppsala University.
This data is part of a publication pending review, ”Structure-Function Walk From an L-Lactaldehyde Reductase to an Aryl-Aldehyde Reductase”, submitted to ChemCatChem on Jan 12 2022 and to ChemBioChem on Feb. 24
2022.

contributors.headline: PhD Candidate in Bone-on-a-chip research at Radboud University Medical Center

projects.title: iGEM Uppsala - 'Biomass destruction'
projects.description:
I participated in the international genetically engineered organism (iGEM) competition of 2019 with the Uppsala university team. Our aim was to make a cocktail of enzymes to break down lignin, the second most common bio-polymer in the world and a waste product from the paper industry, as a first step in making it into specialty chemicals or biofuels.
Along with group members I worked on expressing the desired proteins in yeast cells and programming our wiki. 
I was one of the two people to present our project at the 'giant jamboree' convention of the iGEM competition in Boston, where we received a gold medal for our project.

contributors.headline: PhD Candidate in Bone-on-a-chip research at Radboud University Medical Center

projects.title: High school research project
projects.description:
”The self-organisation of saturated and unsaturated fatty acids and a mix of the two as seen by a scanning tunneling microscope”.
This high school research project was praised as approaching academic levels, and was a runner-up for best high school research project in the school in the category of Nature and Health. 
I did this project together with David Welling. The experiments were done at the Radboud University Nanolab under instruction by Dr J.A.A.W. (Hans) Elemans and Joris. The project supervisor was biology teacher Nico de Boer.
Münninghoff.

contributors.headline: PhD Candidate in Bone-on-a-chip research at Radboud University Medical Center

profile_positions.description: PhD candidate in Bone-on-a-chip research at Radboud University Medical center, in the group Regenerative Biomaterials at the department of Dentistry. My supervisors are Sander Leeuwenburgh and Mani Diba and my research is a part of Mani's Hypathia tenure track project Bone chip predict.
profile_positions.title: PhD candidate in Bone-on-a-chip research at Radboud University Medical Center

volunteer_experiences.description: I was the vice president, education officer and job market officer for the chemistry student association IUPAK in Uppsala.

The primary objective of the iGEM Uppsala organisation is to make sure that a team from Uppsala participates in the International Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) competition each year, and to give continuity to the work on the competition.
I was the secretary of the board and took on projects I was interested in as they came up.
